content.html:
Cool Down Activity

For questions 1–3, what could be added to each expression to make it a perfect square?

  1. \(x^2+12x\)

Enter what could be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Correct! The constant term \(c=36\) can be added to make the perfect square \(x^2+12x+36\).

The correct answer is: The constant term \(c=36\) can be added to make the perfect square \(x^2+12x+36\).

  1. \(x^2−6x+1\)

Enter what could be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Correct! 8 can be added to the constant term \(c=1\) to make the perfect square \(x^2-6x+9\).

The correct answer is: 8 can be added to the constant term \(c=1\) to make the perfect square \(x^2-6x+9\).

  1. \(x^2+14x−10\)

Enter what could be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Correct! 59 can be added to the constant term \(c=-10\) to make the perfect square \(x^2+14x+49\).

The correct answer is: 59 can be added to the constant term \(c=-10\) to make the perfect square \(x^2+14x+49\).

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−16x=-60\) by completing the square. Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}-16 x &=-60 \\ x^{2}-16 x+64 &=-60+64 \\ x^{2}-16 x+64 &=4 \\ (x-8)^{2} &=4 \\ \sqrt{(x-8)^{2}} &=\sqrt{4} \\ x-8 &=\pm 2 \\ x-8 &=2 \\ x-8 &=-2 \\ \\ x=6 & \text { or } x=10 \end{aligned}\)

Cool Down Activity

Learning scientists have found that one of the most powerful things you can do for your learning is to first try answering questions without peeking at your notes. See what you can do from your memory first!

For questions 1–3, what could be added to each expression to make it a perfect square?

  1. \(x^2+12x\)

Enter what could be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Correct! The constant term \(c=36\) can be added to make the perfect square \(x^2+12x+36\).

The correct answer is: The constant term \(c=36\) can be added to make the perfect square \(x^2+12x+36\).

  1. \(x^2−6x+1\)

Enter what could be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Correct! 8 can be added to the constant term \(c=1\) to make the perfect square \(x^2-6x+9\).

The correct answer is: 8 can be added to the constant term \(c=1\) to make the perfect square \(x^2-6x+9\).

  1. \(x^2+14x−10\)

Enter what could be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Correct! 59 can be added to the constant term \(c=-10\) to make the perfect square \(x^2+14x+49\).

The correct answer is: 59 can be added to the constant term \(c=-10\) to make the perfect square \(x^2+14x+49\).

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−16x=-60\) by completing the square. Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}-16 x &=-60 \\ x^{2}-16 x+64 &=-60+64 \\ x^{2}-16 x+64 &=4 \\ (x-8)^{2} &=4 \\ \sqrt{(x-8)^{2}} &=\sqrt{4} \\ x-8 &=\pm 2 \\ x-8 &=2 \\ x-8 &=-2 \\ \\ x=6 & \text { or } x=10 \end{aligned}\)
